{{Infobox individual golf tournament | name = 2011 Masters Tournament | image = [[File:MastersTournamentLogo.svg|120px]] | dates = April 7â10, 2011 | location = [[Augusta, Georgia]] | course = [[Augusta National Golf Club]] | tour = [[PGA Tour]]
[[PGA European Tour]]
[[Japan Golf Tour]] | par = 72 | yardage = 7,435 | field = 99 players, 49 after cut | cut = 145 (+1) | purse = $8,000,000 {{cite web |first=Bill |last=Byler |url=http://apps.augusta.com/masters/news/blogs/inside_the_masters/2011/apr/9/256113-masters_prize_money_increases_to_8_million |title=Inside the Masters |publisher=Augusta.com |date= April 9, 2011 |accessdate=2011-04-11}} | winners_share = $1,440,000 | champion = {{flagicon|ZAF}} [[Charl Schwartzel]] | score = 274 (-14) }} The '''2011 Masters Tournament''' was the 75th [[Masters Tournament]] and was played from April 7â10 at [[Augusta National Golf Club]]. It was the first [[men's major golf championships|major championship]] of the [[2011 in golf|2011]] season. [[South Africa]]n [[Charl Schwartzel]] won the 2011 event by two strokes over [[Adam Scott (golfer)|Adam Scott]] and [[Jason Day (golfer)|Jason Day]].{{cite web |url=http://www.masters.com/en_US/scores/ |title=Leaderboard - 2011 Masters Tournament |publisher=Masters.com |date=April 7, 2011 |accessdate=2011-04-11}} Eight players held a share of the lead in the last round including [[Tiger Woods]] and [[Rory McIlroy]]. McIlroy had at least a share of the lead for the first three rounds and had a four stroke advantage going into Sunday's final round before shooting an 80 and finishing 10 strokes behind Schwartzel.{{cite news |last=Shain |first=Jeff |url= http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-masters-20110411,0,2165950.story |title=South Africa's Charl Schwartzel wins the Masters with a fantastic finish |work=Los Angeles Times |date= April 10, 2011 |accessdate=2011-04-11}} The 2011 Masters was [[Vijay Singh]]'s 67th consecutive major championship and was [[Ben Crenshaw]]'s 40th consecutive Masters appearance. The number one player in the world, [[Martin Kaymer]], failed to make the cut, and [[Hideki Matsuyama]] was the only amateur in the field to play on the weekend.{{cite web |url= http://www.kansascity.com/2011/04/07/2784631/masters-first-round-news-notes.html |title=Masters Second Round News & Notes |work= The Kansas City Star |date=April 7, 2011 |accessdate=2011-04-11}} [[Arnold Palmer]] and [[Jack Nicklaus]] served as honorary starters on Thursday morning, hitting ceremonial tee shots to open the tournament.{{cite web |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ivUnscjgerc_UW99J39wVCNHyrIA?docId=a74c2f284ad548df928b23bc5124fba1 |title=Nicklaus, Palmer get 75th Masters going |work=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=Google.com |date=April 7, 2011 |accessdate=2011-04-11}} ==Field== The Masters has the smallest field of the major championships.{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/golf/news/story?id=5938716 |title=Rankings lead Sean O'Hair, Robert Karlsson into Masters field | publisher= ESPN |date=December 21, 2010 |accessdate=2011-04-11}} Officially the Masters remains an invitation event, but there is a set of qualifying criteria that determines who is included in the field.{{cite web |url= http://www.cbssports.com/golf/tournaments/masters/field |title=Masters |publisher=CBS Sports |accessdate=2011-04-11}} Each player is classified according to the first category by which he qualified, but other categories are shown in parentheses.{{cite web |url=http://golf.about.com/od/majorchampionships/f/masters-qualifications.htm |title= How to Qualify for Masters Tournament |publisher= About.com |date=February 1, 2011 |accessdate=2011-04-11}} Golfers who qualify based solely on their performance in amateur tournaments (categories 6-10) must remain amateurs on the starting day of the tournament to be eligible to play. align=left|[[Vijay Singh]] || align=left|{{FJI}} || 2000 || 76 || 78 || 154 || +10 |- | align=left|[[Ben Crenshaw]] || align=left|{{USA}} || 1984, 1995 || 78 || 77 || 155 || +11 |- | align=left|[[Mike Weir]] || align=left|{{CAN}} || 2003 || 76 || 79 || 155 || +11 |- | align=left|[[Ian Woosnam]] ||align=left|{{WAL}} || 1991 || 78 || 77 || 155 || +11 |} ==First round== [[Rory McIlroy]] and [[Ãlvaro QuirÃ³s]] shot matching 65s to lead after the first round. [[Choi Kyung-Ju|K. J. Choi]] and [[Yang Yong-eun|Y. E. Yang]] each shot 67 to trail by two shots. Defending champion [[Phil Mickelson]], whose lone bogey came at the 18th hole, shot an opening round 70. [[Tiger Woods]] would shoot a -1 (71). [[Henrik Stenson]] struggled to an 83, including a quintuple bogey 8 on the par-3 4th hole, the highest score on the hole in the history of the Masters.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/golf/9452355.stm |title=BBC Sport - Golf - Saturday's Masters golf gossip column |publisher=BBC News |date= April 9, 2011|accessdate=2011-04-11}} {| class="wikitable" !#!!Player!!Country!!Score!!To par |- | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|T1||[[Rory McIlroy]]||{{NIR}}|| rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|65|| rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|-7 |- |[[Ãlvaro QuirÃ³s]]||{{ESP}} |- | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|T3||[[Choi Kyung-Ju|K. J. Choi]]||{{KOR}}|| rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|67|| rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|-5 |- |[[Yang Yong-eun|Y. E. Yang]]||{{KOR}} |- | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|T5||[[Ricky Barnes]]||{{USA}}|| rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|68|| rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|-4 |- |[[Matt Kuchar]]||{{USA}} |- | rowspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|T7||[[Ross Fisher]]||{{ENG}}|| rowspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|69|| rowspan="7" style="text-align:center;"|-3 |- |[[Sergio GarcÃ­a]]||{{ESP}} |- |[[Trevor Immelman]]||{{ZAF}} |- |[[Geoff Ogilvy]]||{{AUS}} |- |[[Charl Schwartzel]]||{{ZAF}} |- |[[Brandt Snedeker]]||{{USA}} |- |[[Gary Woodland]]||{{USA}} |} ==Second round== McIlroy kept his lead by shooting a -3 (69). [[Ãlvaro QuirÃ³s]], the co-leader through 18 holes, shot a +1 (73) to fall back to -6, four shots off the lead. [[Jason Day (golfer)|Jason Day]], in his first Masters appearance, shot a -8 (64) on Friday to move into second place at -8. That was also good for a record second round score for a first time participant. [[Tiger Woods]] shot a -6 (66) to put himself back in the tournament at -7, three shots off the lead. Woods shot 31 on the back nine to charge up the leaderboard. [[Choi Kyung-Ju|K. J. Choi]] shot a -2 (70) to move to -7 into third place along with Woods. Notable players who missed the cut were [[Graeme McDowell]], [[Martin Kaymer]], [[PÃ¡draig Harrington]], and [[Hunter Mahan]]. {| class="wikitable" !#!!Player!!Country!!Score!!To par |- | style="text-align:center;"|1||[[Rory McIlroy]]||{{NIR}}|| style="text-align:center;"|65-69=134|| style="text-align:center;"|-10 |- | style="text-align:center;"|2||[[Jason Day (golfer)|Jason Day]]||{{AUS}}|| style="text-align:center;"|72-64=136|| style="text-align:center;"|-8 |- | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|T3||[[Choi Kyung-Ju|K. J. Choi]]||{{KOR}}||67-70=137|| rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|-7 |- |[[Tiger Woods]]||{{USA}}||71-66=137 |- | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|T5||[[Geoff Ogilvy]]||{{AUS}}||69-69=138|| rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|-6 |- |[[Ãlvaro QuirÃ³s]]||{{ESP}}||65-73=138 |- | rowspan="5" style="text-align:center;"|T7||[[Ricky Barnes]]||{{USA}}||68-71=139|| rowspan="5" style="text-align:center;"|-5 |- |[[Fred Couples]]||{{USA}}||71-68=139 |- |[[Rickie Fowler]]||{{USA}}||70-69=139 |- |[[Lee Westwood]]||{{ENG}}||72-67=139 |- |[[Yang Yong-eun|Y. E. Yang]]||{{KOR}}||67-72=139 |} Amateurs: ''[[Hideki Matsuyama|Matsuyama]] (+1)'', [[David Chung (golfer)|Chung]] (+4), Kim (+4), [[Peter Uihlein|Uihlein]] (+5), [[Jin Jeong|Jeong]] (+6), Smith (+8). ==Third round== [[Rory McIlroy]] held at least a share of the lead for the third straight day. After playing the first 12 holes in one over par, he birdied 13, 15 and 17 to gain a four shot lead. 2009 champion [[Ãngel Cabrera]] stormed into second place with a 67 to play in the final pairing on Sunday for the second time in three years. [[Jason Day (golfer)|Jason Day]], who held the outright lead after hole 5, shot 72 and was also 4 shots back. [[Tiger Woods]] struggled to a 74 after a 66 on Friday. Cabrera, [[Bubba Watson]] and [[Adam Scott (golfer)|Adam Scott]] all shot 67, the round of the day.{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/10/sports/golf/10masters.html |title=McIlroy Continues to Set Pace, and Field Struggles to Keep Up |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |first=Larry |last=Dorman |date=April 9, 2011 |accessdate=2011-04-11}} {| class="wikitable" !#!!Player!!Country!!Score!!To par |- | style="text-align:center;"|1||[[Rory McIlroy]]||{{NIR}}|| style="text-align:center;"|65-69-70=204|| style="text-align:center;"|-12 |- | rowspan="4" style="text-align:center;"|T2||[[Ãngel Cabrera]]||{{ARG}}||71-70-67=208|| rowspan="4" style="text-align:center;"|-8 |- |[[Choi Kyung-Ju|K. J. Choi]]||{{KOR}}||67-70-71=208 |- |[[Jason Day (golfer)|Jason Day]]||{{AUS}}||72-64-72=208 |- |[[Charl Schwartzel]]||{{ZAF}}||69-71-68=208 |- | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|T6||[[Luke Donald]]||{{ENG}}||72-68-69=209|| rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|-7 |- |[[Adam Scott (golfer)|Adam Scott]]||{{AUS}}||72-70-67=209 |- | style="text-align:center;"|8||[[Bo Van Pelt]]||{{USA}}||73-69-68=210|| style="text-align:center;"|-6 |- | rowspan="5" style="text-align:center;"|T9||[[Fred Couples]]||{{USA}}||71-68-72=211|| rowspan="5" style="text-align:center;"|-5 |- |[[Ross Fisher]]||{{ENG}}||69-71-71=211 |- |[[Geoff Ogilvy]]||{{AUS}}||69-69-73=211 |- |[[Bubba Watson]]||{{USA}}||73-71-67=211 |- |[[Tiger Woods]]||{{USA}}||71-66-74=211 |} ==Final round== Eight different players had at least a share of the lead at one point during the final round, included five simultaneously on the back 9. 54 hole leader [[Rory McIlroy]] shot 37 on the front to hold onto the lead, but made triple bogey on 10 and a 4 putt double bogey on 12 to fade with a final round 80. [[Tiger Woods]], who was seven shots back to start the final round, shot 31 on the front nine including an eagle at 8. He eventually tied for the lead, but a three-putt bogey on 12 and a missed 5-foot eagle putt on 15 doomed his chance at a fifth Masters title. Woods has never come from behind in the final round to win any of his 14 major victories. [[Geoff Ogilvy]], also seven shots back to start the day, birdied 12 through 16 to share the lead, but came up short of his second major. [[Choi Kyung-Ju|K. J. Choi]] tied for the lead with a birdie at the 9th hole, but struggled putting on the back nine and finished in a tie for 8th. 2009 champion [[Ãngel Cabrera]] led for much of the back 9, but bogeys at 12 and 16 lead to a solo 7th place finish. [[Adam Scott (golfer)|Adam Scott]] stormed up the leader board and after a birdie at 16 he held a two shot lead. [[Jason Day (golfer)|Jason Day]] made a 35 foot birdie putt on 17 and another birdie on 18 to post -12, a share of the clubhouse lead with Scott. However the day belonged to [[Charl Schwartzel]], who chipped in for birdie at 1, holed out for eagle on 3 and birdied the last 4 holes to come back and win by two shots. Schwartzel's 66 was the low round of the day. It was Schwartzel's first major win, and he became the third South African to win the Masters along with [[Gary Player]] and [[Trevor Immelman]]. It was also the 50th anniversary of Player's 1961 Masters win (when he became both the first South African and international player to win the Masters. {| class="wikitable" !#!!Player!!Country!!Score!!To par |- | style="text-align:center;"|1||'''[[Charl Schwartzel]]'''||{{ZAF}}||69-71-68-66=274||rowspan"1" style="text-align:center;"|-14 |- | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|T2||[[Jason Day (golfer)|Jason Day]]||{{AUS}}||72-64-72-68=276|| rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|-12 |- |[[Adam Scott (golfer)|Adam Scott]]||{{AUS}}||72-70-67-67=276 |- | rowspan="3" style="text-align:center;"|T4||[[Luke Donald]]||{{ENG}}||72-68-69-69=278|| rowspan="3" style="text-align:center;"|-10 |- |[[Geoff Ogilvy]]||{{AUS}}||69-69-73-67=278 |- |[[Tiger Woods]]||{{USA}}||71-66-74-67=278 |- | style="text-align:center;"|7||[[Ãngel Cabrera]]||{{ARG}}||71-70-67-71=279||align=center|-9 |- | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|T8||[[Choi Kyung-Ju|K. J. Choi]]||{{KOR}}||67-70-71-72=280|| rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;"|-8 |- |[[Bo Van Pelt]]||{{USA}}||73-69-68-70=280 |- | style="text-align:center;"|10||[[Ryan Palmer]]||{{USA}}||71-72-69-70=282||align=center|-6 |} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.masters.com/}} *[http://www.golfobserver.com/new/golfstats.php?style=&tour=Majors&name=&year=2011&tournament=Masters&in=Search Full Results] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before=[[2010 PGA Championship]]| title=[[Men's major golf championships|Major Championships]] | years= | after=[[2011 U.S. Open (golf)|2011 U.S. Open]]}} {{s-end}} {{Golf Major Championships master|2011}} {{Masters Tournaments}} [[Category:2011 in American sports|Masters]] [[Category:2011 in Georgia (U.S. state)|Masters]] [[Category:2011 in golf|Masters Tournament]] [[Category:Masters Tournament]] [[fr:Masters de golf de 2011]] [[nl:Masters Tournament 2011 (golf)]]
